hints_html:
Your first reaction might be to use the theory of Pell equations and continued fractions on this problem, but there is a much more elegant solution.

Suppose that in fact d was of the form \(\displaystyle 4n + 3\). What can we conclude about prime divisors of d?

Recall that the product of two primes of the form \(\displaystyle 4k + 1\) must be a number of the form \(\displaystyle 4m + 1\).

Use a sub-case of quadratic reciprocity or Euler’s criterion to finish the problem.

hints_raw:
Your first reaction might be to use the theory of Pell equations and continued fractions on this problem, but there is a much more elegant solution.
Suppose that in fact ''d'' was of the form <math> \displaystyle 4n + 3 </math>. What can we conclude about prime divisors of ''d''?
Recall that the product of two primes of the form <math> \displaystyle 4k + 1 </math> must be a number of the form <math> \displaystyle 4m + 1 </math>.
Use a sub-case of quadratic reciprocity or Euler's criterion to finish the problem.
sols_html:
We proceed as in the hints. Suppose that in fact d was of the form \(\displaystyle 4n + 3\). Then since

\(\displaystyle (4k + 1)(4m+1) = 4(4km + k + m) + 1\)

we know that there must be a prime p of the form \(\displaystyle p = 4j + 3\) that divides d. Reducing modulo p gives

\(\displaystyle x^{2} \equiv -1 \mod{p}\)

This means that \(\displaystyle \left(\frac{-1}{p} \right) = 1\). However, Euler’s criterion tells us that \(\displaystyle 1 = \left(\frac{-1}{p} \right) \equiv (-1)^{(p-1)/2} = (-1)^{2j+1} =-1 \mod{p}\) and this is a contradiction.

statement_html: Show that if d is an odd squarefree integer then a necessary condition for the equation \(\displaystyle x^2 -d y^2 = -1\) to have an integer solution is that all the primes dividing d must be of the form \(\displaystyle 4n + 1\).
